abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Roads Project in
            Romania were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the
            risk to development outcome was moderate, the Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and the borrower performance
            was satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: That a
            holistic approach to road safety is necessary involving the
            three 'Ed' engineering, enforcement, and education
            to bring down the national accident rate. In the Romania
            Second Roads project this approach has had some success, but
            it was found that a good coordinating body is essential to
            bring together departments and entities unused to working
            together, while continued political commitment is important
            to sustain the initiative once this process has begun. In
            Romania a renewed, action-oriented emphasis is needed to
            ensure that the positive progress achieved to date is
            continued. The road improvement program was effective, but
            the Romanian experience highlights the importance of
            forecasting traffic as accurately as possible, of ensuring
            there is a clear plan to fund road maintenance activities,
            and of ensuring that there is an appropriate protocol in
            place for the relocation of utilities. In the Romania Second
            Roads Project specific arrangements could have been made to
            protect small works contractors facing a very steep rise in
            inflationary costs. Although a price escalation clause is
            not usually included in such contracts, it could be argued
            that force major circumstances applied in this particular
            case. Complex road safety programs can benefit greatly from
            continuous and coordinated partnerships between
            international organizations over an extended time period.
            The Romania Second Roads project exemplifies the manner in
            which the partners were able to provide additional support
            at short notice when one of the components had a finding shortfall.

abstracts.cdata!:
Ratings for the Second Roads Project in
            Romania were as follows: outcomes were satisfactory, the
            risk to development outcome was low or negligible, the Bank
            performance was satisfactory, and the Borrower performance
            was satisfactory. Some lessons learned included: 1)
            Contingency plans would be useful when grant funding is not
            fully secured; 2) The merit of extending the closing date of
            loans to use remaining funds requires careful assessment.
            The project provided a useful learning process to Romania
            National Company for Motorways and National Roads (RNCMNR)
            on how to deal with utility relocations and land
            acquisition, and motivated the company to improve detailed
            engineering design in general; 3) All road projects
            involving civil works particularly within urban areas,
            should agree beforehand how the utilities will be dealt with
            and the responsibilities for doing so; and 4) Co-financing
            and its time table must be agreed in writing.

abstracts.cdata!:
The objectives of the Second Roads
            Project are to: (1) improve traffic safety and vehicle fleet
            fitness; (2) continue helping Romania to meet changing
            demand for land transport infrastructure; (3) improve the
            management and performance of the road administration (NAR);
            (4) assist the Romanian civil works construction industry in
            its transition to a market economy; (5) promote lead
            reduction in petrol; and (6) assist Romania to harmonize the
            standards of its road network, of its vehicles and their
            safety, and of the institutional practices of NAR with those
            of the European Union. The project consists of five
            components: (a) road and bridge rehabilitation, to include
            overlaying, construction and reconstruction, widening, and
            geometric improvements; (b) a traffic safety program
            involving education, engineering, and enforcement; (c)
            institution building involving NAR computerization, the
            introduction of bridge and pavement management systems,
            transport planning, privatization of maintenance and
            installation; (d) assistance to the civil works and
            construction industry, training programs and equipment
            financing; and (e) an action plan to reduce lead in petrol.
